title: How can people judge a cover by its book? - Quora

response.answer_text: You consider the communication expressed on it. Think about it. Literally, a book usually has a title and perhaps a ‘trailer’ type description on the back, intended to make it enticing to its target audience. So you can tell a lot about a book by its cover, though how much varies with the book. Some books seem to rely on their own fame, or the authors - To Kill A Mockingbird hardly screams ‘Grab me off the shelf!’ to me. Now consider the figurative use of the phrase; judging people, most commonly. Ah, but people make choices in their grooming and attire, yes? Their posture, accent, word choice… they project a lot of data, info., hints about themselves. Now, it’s important to be mindful of the limits of what you can tell. Sometimes what’s inside is quite a surprise vs. what you might’ve guessed from outward appearances. But you can’t get to know everyone around you, anymore than you can read every book on the shelf at the bookstore. Since you’ve got limited time, energy and inclination, you use covers to judge where to focus your energies and dig deeper, hoping to find whatever it is you’re looking for, while excluding less profitable options that would be a waste of your time and energy. That’s how and why.
